   Last dose of Antibiotics:

   Other labs: PT / PTT / INR:27.5/42.6/2.7, CK / CKMB /
   Troponin-T:324/20/1.03, Lactic Acid:0.9 mmol/L, Ca++:7.4 mg/dL,
   Mg++:1.7 mg/dL, PO4:2.8 mg/dL
   Assessment and Plan
   85yF with hx of severe AS and recent pulmonary embolus on coumadin
   admitted with GI bleeding and respiratory distress.
   #) GI bleeding--likely precipitated from supratherapeutic INR and
   ascriptin use. Unclear whether bleeding is from upper GI or lower GI
   source. Hct 22.7 --> 26.3 with 2U. Not actively bleeding this AM, NGT
   lavage negative.
   - Access: 4 PIVs
   - Transfusing one more unit this AM for goal Hct >28.
   - Obtain post-transfusion Hct
   - Q4-6H  Hct until stable
   - INR 2.7: hold off on more FFP since patient is not actively bleeding
   now.
   - Continue on protonix drip per GI (18mg bolus and 8mg/hr infusion)
   - Plan for EGD this AM. Can consider outpatient colonoscopy depending
   on results of EGD.
   - If EGD negative and Pt continuing to bleed, consider tagged RBC scan.
   Will discuss possible scan with IR and notify surgery
   - Appreciate GI recs
   - If continues to bleed, will consider possibility of additional FFP
   and possible IVC filter
    - Monitor closely, if worsens would involve surgery / IR
   #) Respiratory distress--most likely due to flash pulmonary edema from
   AS in the setting of transfusion, IVF. Acute anemia may be
   contributing. Although no obvious changes to EKG, cannot exclude
   myocardial ischemia given this patient's risk factors for CAD and
   recent acute bleeding, as well as long-standing LBBB making EKG
   difficult to interpret for ischemia. Also can baseline respiratory
   distress from recent history of pulmonary embolus. Unlikely new PE
   given supratherapeutic INR.
   - Continue mechanical ventilation; Most recent EKG shows alkalemia 7.49
   pCO2 38; continue to adjust vent settings to optimize pH and pCO2.
   - Will plan to transition vent settings to pressure support, but will
   maintain on respirator for now
   - As blood pressure improves may need to control tachycardia with
   judicious use of Lopressor to optimize diastolic filling for
   improvement of cardiac output in the setting of severe aortic stenosis
   (hold for now given unstable blood volume)
   - Judicious use of lasix during transfusion for aortic stenosis; may
   need to focus on GIB now with plan to optimize pulmonary status as HD
   improves
   - [**Month (only) 51**] benefit from PA line to monitor LVEDV/preload and guide
   therapeutic decision-making for lasix dosing as HD improves
   - BPs fine; no need for CVL at this time.
   - f/u final CXR read--pulmonary edema vs. multifocal PNA.
   - Hold antibiotics for now given no e/o infection
   - F/u final read LENIs (prelim negative)
    - Arterial line for improved HD monitoring
   - Conside use of Vigileo for continuous assessment for fluid
   responsiveness
   #) Myocardial ischemia--troponin bumped from 0.11 --> 1.03, too high to
   be considered elevated from demand ischemia in the setting of GI bleed.
   Repeat EKG shows no changes from prior but difficult to interpret in
   setting of LBBB.
   - Receive high-dose lipitor 80mg today
   - Holding off on beta-blocker due to severe AS, heparin and ASA due to
   bleed
   - Continue cardiac enzymes to determine if levels decreasing/increasing
   - Will continue to monitor on telemetry
   - q8h EKG and cardiac enzymes
   - Possibly cardiology consult for possible cath pending resolution of
   GI bleeding.
   #) Severe AS--Last echo [**2177-2-25**] shows preserved EF 55-60% but patient
   is symptomatic and difficult to fluid resuscitate.  No reported valve
   area
 will obtain Echo report from OSH.
   - Judicious use of beta blockers to maintain adequate HR to ensure
   adequate diastolic filling time (preload dependence) if tachycardic
   - Judicious use of lasix during transfusion to prevent both flash
   pulmonary edema and decreased pre-load.
   - [**Month (only) 51**] benefit from PA catheter placement as above
   - Out-patient discussion of aortic valve replacement
   #) Pulmonary embolus--Currently therapeutically anticoagulated.  Per
   OSH records, small and sub-segmental.  Negative LENIs.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] INR
   - LENIs; f/u final read.
   #) Type II DM
 Unclear level of control.
   - Hold home glipizide
   - Insulin sliding scale with finger sticks qAC and HS
   #) Osteoarthritis--NSAIDs contraindicated for pain relief. Patient
   currently on Fentanyl / Midazolam gtt
   - Monitor for pain control, Fentanyl gtt
    - Hold outpatient po medications for now
    - Hold all NSAIDs
   #) Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree--noted on OSH CTA without
   work-up.  Per family, no complaint of abdominal pain prior to
   admission.
   - LFTs and alk phos
   - When stable, will consider RUQ ultrasound
   #) Hypercholesterolemia--80 atorvastatin for myocardial ischemia.
   # LUE pain: Etiology unclear.  [**Name2 (NI) 54**] family, this was the patient
   primary complaint today.  Prior OSH records with negative LUE u/s.
   Also with history of possible bursitis.  Given acute bleed and h/o CAD,
   obviously concerning for cardiac ischemia.
    - CE as above, ROMI
    - Control pain
    - Evaluate further as course progresses, when patient able to provide
   more details
    - Could consider x-ray of shoulder though no h/o trauma
   #) FEN:
   - Judicious fluid resuscitation given AS; A-line for improved HD
   monitoring
   - NPO for possible scope tomorrow
   - Replete lytes PRN
   #) Prophylaxis:
   - INR 2.7; holding heparin
   - Pneumoboots
   - Chlorhexadine glucontate / IV PPI gtt; daily wake-ups
   - HOB > 30 degrees
   #) Access
   -18X1 and 20 X3, PIVs
   - R arterial line
   - Needs CVL
   #) Communication: Patient and daughter (Family meeting held on arrival
   to ICU, HCP [**Name (NI) 11111**] [**Name (NI) 13842**] [**0-0-**], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 13843**] (cell)
   #) Code:  FULL CODE
   #) Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's condition as follows:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis (AS), recent pulmonary embolus (PE), and type II diabetes mellitus (DM). She was admitted with gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding and respiratory distress. The patient has undergone transfusions, including 4 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 2 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP), and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation.

The patient's current vital signs include:

* Temperature: 38°C (100.4°F)
* Heart rate: 67 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 133/45 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 100%
* Hemodynamic monitoring: central venous pressure (CVP) 10 mmHg, pulmonary artery pressure (PAP) 25 mmHg, and cardiac output (CO) 3.5 L/min

The patient's laboratory results include:

* Hemoglobin: 26.3 g/dL
* Platelet count: 295 K/uL
* White blood cell count: 8.8 K/uL
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 27 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
* Troponin-T: 1.03 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.9 mmol/L
* Calcium: 7.4 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 1.7 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 2.8 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Severe AS
* Recent PE
* Type II DM
* Osteoarthritis
* Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree
* Hypercholesterolemia
* LUE pain (etiology unclear)

The patient's medications include:

* Fentanyl (concentrate) 25 mcg/hour
* Pantoprazole (Protonix) 8 mg/hour
* Midazolam (Versed) 0.5 mg/hour
* Insulin sliding scale with finger sticks qAC and HS
* Lipitor 80 mg/day

The patient's plan includes:

* Transfusing one more unit of PRBCs for a goal hemoglobin >28 g/dL
* Obtaining post-transfusion hemoglobin levels
* Q4-6H hemoglobin monitoring until stable
* Holding off on more FFP since the patient is not actively bleeding
* Continuing protonix drip per GI
* Planning for an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) this morning
* Considering a tagged red blood cell (RBC) scan if the patient continues to bleed
* Monitoring for respiratory distress and adjusting ventilator settings as needed
* Considering a cardiology consult for possible cardiac catheterization pending resolution of GI bleeding
* Judicious use of beta-blockers to maintain adequate heart rate to ensure adequate diastolic filling time
* Judicious use of lasix during transfusion to prevent both flash pulmonary edema and decreased preload
* Considering a PA catheter placement as above
* Outpatient discussion of aortic valve replacement

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Continued bleeding from the GI tract
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac ischemia
* Pulmonary edema
* Hypovolemic shock
* Acute kidney injury
* Infection
* Hepatic failure

I recommend that the patient's condition be closely monitored, and any changes in her condition be promptly addressed to prevent potential complications.

   ascriptin use. Unclear whether bleeding is from upper GI or lower GI
   source. Hct 22.7 --> 26.3 with 2U. Not actively bleeding this AM, NGT
   lavage negative.
   - Access: 4 PIVs
   - Transfusing one more unit this AM for goal Hct >28.
   - Obtain post-transfusion Hct
   - Q4-6H  Hct until stable
   - INR 2.7: hold off on more FFP since patient is not actively bleeding
   now.
   - Continue on protonix drip per GI (18mg bolus and 8mg/hr infusion)
   - Plan for EGD this AM. Can consider outpatient colonoscopy depending
   on results of EGD.
   - If EGD negative and Pt continuing to bleed, consider tagged RBC scan.
   Will discuss possible scan with IR and notify surgery
   - Appreciate GI recs
   - If continues to bleed, will consider possibility of additional FFP
   and possible IVC filter
    - Monitor closely, if worsens would involve surgery / IR
   #) Respiratory distress--most likely due to flash pulmonary edema from
   AS in the setting of transfusion, IVF. Acute anemia may be
   contributing. Although no obvious changes to EKG, cannot exclude
   myocardial ischemia given this patient's risk factors for CAD and
   recent acute bleeding, as well as long-standing LBBB making EKG
   difficult to interpret for ischemia. Also can baseline respiratory
   distress from recent history of pulmonary embolus. Unlikely new PE
   given supratherapeutic INR.
   - Continue mechanical ventilation; Most recent EKG shows alkalemia 7.49
   pCO2 38; continue to adjust vent settings to optimize pH and pCO2.
   - Will plan to transition vent settings to pressure support, but will
   maintain on respirator for now
   - As blood pressure improves may need to control tachycardia with
   judicious use of Lopressor to optimize diastolic filling for
   improvement of cardiac output in the setting of severe aortic stenosis
   (hold for now given unstable blood volume)
   - Judicious use of lasix during transfusion for aortic stenosis; may
   need to focus on GIB now with plan to optimize pulmonary status as HD
   improves
   - [**Month (only) 51**] benefit from PA line to monitor LVEDV/preload and guide
   therapeutic decision-making for lasix dosing as HD improves
   - BPs fine; no need for CVL at this time.
   - f/u final CXR read--pulmonary edema vs. multifocal PNA.
   - Hold antibiotics for now given no e/o infection
   - F/u final read LENIs (prelim negative)
    - Arterial line for improved HD monitoring
   - Conside use of Vigileo for continuous assessment for fluid
   responsiveness
   #) Myocardial ischemia--troponin bumped from 0.11 --> 1.03, too high to
   be considered elevated from demand ischemia in the setting of GI bleed.
   Repeat EKG shows no changes from prior but difficult to interpret in
   setting of LBBB.
   - Receive high-dose lipitor 80mg today
   - Holding off on beta-blocker due to severe AS, heparin and ASA due to
   bleed
   - Continue cardiac enzymes to determine if levels decreasing/increasing
   - Will continue to monitor on telemetry
   - q8h EKG and cardiac enzymes
   - Possibly cardiology consult for possible cath pending resolution of
   GI bleeding.
   #) Severe AS--Last echo [**2177-2-25**] shows preserved EF 55-60% but patient
   is symptomatic and difficult to fluid resuscitate.  No reported valve
   area
 will obtain Echo report from OSH.
   - Judicious use of beta blockers to maintain adequate HR to ensure
   adequate diastolic filling time (preload dependence) if tachycardic
   - Judicious use of lasix during transfusion to prevent both flash
   pulmonary edema and decreased pre-load.
   - [**Month (only) 51**] benefit from PA catheter placement as above
   - Out-patient discussion of aortic valve replacement
   #) Pulmonary embolus--Currently therapeutically anticoagulated.  Per
   OSH records, small and sub-segmental.  Negative LENIs.
   - [**Hospital1 7**] INR
   - LENIs; f/u final read.
   #) Type II DM
 Unclear level of control.
   - Hold home glipizide
   - Insulin sliding scale with finger sticks qAC and HS
   #) Osteoarthritis--NSAIDs contraindicated for pain relief. Patient
   currently on Fentanyl / Midazolam gtt
   - Monitor for pain control, Fentanyl gtt
    - Hold outpatient po medications for now
    - Hold all NSAIDs
   #) Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree--noted on OSH CTA without
   work-up.  Per family, no complaint of abdominal pain prior to
   admission.
   - LFTs and alk phos
   - When stable, will consider RUQ ultrasound
   #) Hypercholesterolemia--80 atorvastatin for myocardial ischemia.
   # LUE pain: Etiology unclear.  [**Name2 (NI) 54**] family, this was the patient
   primary complaint today.  Prior OSH records with negative LUE u/s.
   Also with history of possible bursitis.  Given acute bleed and h/o CAD,
   obviously concerning for cardiac ischemia.
    - CE as above, ROMI
    - Control pain
    - Evaluate further as course progresses, when patient able to provide
   more details
    - Could consider x-ray of shoulder though no h/o trauma
   #) FEN:
   - Judicious fluid resuscitation given AS; A-line for improved HD
   monitoring
   - NPO for possible scope tomorrow
   - Replete lytes PRN
   #) Prophylaxis:
   - INR 2.7; holding heparin
   - Pneumoboots
   - Chlorhexadine glucontate / IV PPI gtt; daily wake-ups
   - HOB > 30 degrees
   #) Access
   -18X1 and 20 X3, PIVs
   - R arterial line
   - Needs CVL
   #) Communication: Patient and daughter (Family meeting held on arrival
   to ICU, HCP [**Name (NI) 11111**] [**Name (NI) 13842**] [**0-0-**], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 13843**] (cell)
   #) Code:  FULL CODE
   #) Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

Summary:

The patient, an 85-year-old female with severe aortic stenosis (AS) and recent pulmonary embolus, was admitted to the ICU with gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding and respiratory distress. She received 4 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and 2 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) overnight. Her hemoglobin (Hb) level has increased from 22.7 to 26.3 g/dL with transfusion. She is still bleeding, but not actively bleeding this morning. The patient's respiratory status is improving, but she remains intubated and ventilated.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. GI bleeding: The patient's GI bleeding is likely due to supratherapeutic international normalized ratio (INR) and ascriptin use. Further bleeding may occur, and the patient may require additional transfusions.
2. Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory distress is likely due to flash pulmonary edema from AS in the setting of transfusion and intravenous fluids (IVF). She may require further adjustments to her ventilator settings to optimize pH and pCO2.
3. Myocardial ischemia: The patient's troponin level has increased, indicating possible myocardial ischemia. Further cardiac enzymes will be monitored to determine if levels are decreasing or increasing.
4. Severe AS: The patient's severe AS may lead to cardiac output issues, and she may require judicious use of beta-blockers and lasix to maintain adequate diastolic filling time.
5. Pulmonary embolus: The patient has a history of pulmonary embolus, and her INR is currently therapeutic. Further monitoring is necessary to ensure that she does not develop another pulmonary embolism.
6. Type II DM: The patient's blood glucose levels will need to be closely monitored, and she will require insulin sliding scale with finger sticks qAC and HS.
7. Osteoarthritis: The patient's pain will need to be monitored, and she will require judicious use of fentanyl and midazolam infusions.
8. Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree: The patient's dilated intrahepatic biliary tree may require further evaluation and treatment.
9. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's hypercholesterolemia will need to be managed with high-dose atorvastatin.
10. LUE pain: The patient's LUE pain is unclear, and further evaluation may be necessary to determine the etiology.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's GI bleeding and respiratory status closely.
2. Adjust ventilator settings as necessary to optimize pH and pCO2.
3. Continue to monitor cardiac enzymes and consider cardiology consult for possible cath pending resolution of GI bleeding.
4. Manage the patient's pain with judicious use of fentanyl and midazolam infusions.
5. Monitor the patient's blood glucose levels closely and adjust insulin sliding scale as necessary.
6. Consider outpatient colonoscopy depending on the results of EGD.
7. Monitor the patient's INR and adjust anticoagulation therapy as necessary.
8. Consider tagged RBC scan if the patient continues to bleed.
9. Monitor the patient's LUE pain and consider further evaluation.
10. Plan for EGD this morning and consider outpatient aortic valve replacement.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis (AS), recent pulmonary embolus, and type II diabetes. She was admitted with gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding and respiratory distress. She is currently intubated and on invasive ventilation, with a central venous line (CVL) and arterial line in place. Her lab results show elevated troponin levels, indicating possible myocardial ischemia. She is also at risk for flash pulmonary edema due to her AS and transfusion.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Continued GI bleeding: The patient's GI bleeding may continue to worsen, leading to further anemia, hypovolemia, and potential cardiac complications.
2. Myocardial ischemia: The patient's elevated troponin levels and history of CAD make her at risk for ongoing myocardial ischemia, which could lead to further cardiac complications.
3. Flash pulmonary edema: The patient's AS and transfusion make her at risk for flash pulmonary edema, which could worsen her respiratory distress.
4. Cardiac tamponade: The patient's severe AS and recent pulmonary embolus make her at risk for cardiac tamponade, which could worsen her cardiac output.
5. Infection: The patient's prolonged hospitalization and invasive lines make her at risk for infection, which could worsen her condition.
6. Pneumonia: The patient's respiratory distress and recent pulmonary embolus make her at risk for pneumonia, which could worsen her respiratory status.
7. Kidney injury: The patient's hypovolemia and potential cardiac complications make her at risk for kidney injury, which could worsen her overall condition.
8. Osteoporosis: The patient's history of osteoarthritis and recent fall make her at risk for osteoporosis, which could worsen her bone health.
9. Biliary obstruction: The patient's dilated intrahepatic biliary tree and recent CTA make her at risk for biliary obstruction, which could worsen her liver function.
10. Shoulder pain: The patient's LUE pain and history of possible bursitis make her at risk for shoulder pain, which could worsen her overall condition.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's GI bleeding and adjust therapy as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's myocardial ischemia and adjust therapy as needed.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust therapy as needed.
4. Consider placing a pulmonary artery (PA) catheter to monitor the patient's cardiac output and guide therapy.
5. Consider consulting cardiology to further evaluate the patient's cardiac status and potential need for catheterization.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust therapy as needed.
7. Consider placing a nasogastric tube (NGT) to monitor the patient's GI bleeding and adjust therapy as needed.
8. Consider consulting gastroenterology to further evaluate the patient's GI bleeding and potential need for endoscopy.
9. Continue to monitor the patient's pain and adjust therapy as needed.
10. Consider consulting orthopedics to further evaluate the patient's LUE pain and potential need for further evaluation.

Based on the physician's daily progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis, recent pulmonary embolus, and type II diabetes. She was admitted to the ICU with GI bleeding and respiratory distress.

The patient's vital signs are:

* Temperature: 102.5°F (39.2°C)
* Heart rate: 55 bpm
* Blood pressure: 121/40 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 15 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 98%

The patient has been transfused with 2U FFP and 1U PRBCs, and has received lasix 10mg IV x3. She has also been given fentanyl and midazolam infusions.

The patient's lab results show:

* Hemoglobin: 26.8%
* Platelet count: 294,000/μL
* WBC count: 10.7 x 10^9/L
* Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 34 mg/dL
* Creatinine: 0.6 mg/dL
* Troponin: 1.50 ng/mL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L
* LDH: 290 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase: 191 IU/L
* Total bilirubin: 1.0 mg/dL

The patient's ECHO results show mild regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with focal hypokinesis of the distal half of the septum and thinning/akinesis of the distal anterior wall and apex. There is also severe aortic valve stenosis, moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension, and mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

The patient's diagnosis is complicated by her history of severe aortic stenosis, recent pulmonary embolus, and type II diabetes. The patient's symptoms include GI bleeding, respiratory distress, and fever.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Ongoing bleeding: The patient's hemoglobin level is still dropping, and she may require further transfusions.
2. Myocardial ischemia: The patient's troponin level is elevated, and she may be at risk for further myocardial damage.
3. Infection: The patient has a fever and may be at risk for hospital-acquired infections.
4. Pulmonary embolism: The patient has a history of pulmonary embolus and may be at risk for further clot formation.
5. Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree: The patient's liver function tests are mildly elevated, and she may be at risk for further liver damage.
6. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient's cholesterol level is elevated, and she may be at risk for further cardiovascular complications.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Continued monitoring of her vital signs and lab results.
2. Further transfusions as needed to maintain her hemoglobin level.
3. Treatment of her fever with antibiotics if necessary.
4. Management of her respiratory distress with CPAP/PS and possible intubation.
5. Evaluation of her myocardial ischemia with further cardiac enzymes and possible cardiology consult.
6. Monitoring of her liver function tests and possible evaluation of her dilated intrahepatic biliary tree with RUQ ultrasound.
7. Management of her hypercholesterolemia with statins and possible further treatment.
8. Evaluation of her osteoarthritis with possible x-ray of her shoulder and further treatment as needed.
9. Management of her pain with fentanyl and possible further treatment.
10. Further evaluation of her LUE pain with possible x-ray of her shoulder and further treatment as needed.

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female admitted to the ICU with a history of severe aortic stenosis, recent pulmonary embolus, and gastrointestinal bleeding. She is currently being treated for a bleeding disorder and has undergone transfusions with packed red blood cells and fresh frozen plasma. She is also being managed for respiratory distress, myocardial ischemia, and fever.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated troponin levels, indicating possible myocardial infarction, and mildly elevated liver enzymes, possibly indicating liver ischemia. Her electrolyte levels are mildly abnormal, and she has a high bilirubin level, possibly indicating hemolysis.

The patient's physical examination reveals a harsh crescendo/decrescendo murmur heard diffusely through the precordium, consistent with aortic stenosis. Her lungs are clear to auscultation, and her abdomen is soft and non-tender.

Potential medical complications:

1. Continued bleeding: The patient's bleeding disorder and recent transfusions may lead to further bleeding, which could be life-threatening.
2. Myocardial infarction: The patient's elevated troponin levels and history of myocardial ischemia increase her risk of myocardial infarction, which could be fatal.
3. Liver damage: The patient's mildly elevated liver enzymes and high bilirubin level may indicate liver damage, which could lead to liver failure.
4. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress and possible pulmonary edema increase her risk of respiratory failure, which could be fatal.
5. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate an infection, which could be severe and life-threatening.
6. Hemolysis: The patient's high bilirubin level and mildly elevated liver enzymes may indicate hemolysis, which could lead to further complications.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding disorder and transfusion requirements closely.
2. Monitor the patient's troponin levels and myocardial function to assess for possible myocardial infarction.
3. Continue to manage the patient's respiratory distress and possible pulmonary edema with mechanical ventilation and diuretics.
4. Monitor the patient's liver enzymes and bilirubin level to assess for possible liver damage.
5. Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust her fluid and electrolyte management accordingly.
6. Consider empiric antibiotic therapy for possible infection.
7. Consider further testing to evaluate for possible hemolysis, such as a hemolysis panel and a liver ultrasound.

   Assessment and Plan
   85yF with hx of severe AS and recent pulmonary embolus on coumadin
   admitted with GI bleeding and respiratory distress.
   #) GI bleeding--likely precipitated from supratherapeutic INR and
   ascriptin use. Likely lower GI source given negative NGT lavage and
   BRBPR. Hct 22.7 --> 26.3 --> 29.2 --> 25.2 after 4U PRBs, which is
   concerning for ongoing bleeding although there is no clinical signs of
   this and patient's coagulopathy has corrected with FFP and vitamin K
   5mg IV x1.
   - Continue to follow-up Hct; if continues to worsen will obtain nuclear
   red blood cell scan with possibility of angiography
   - Access: 4 [**Last Name (LF) 5258**], [**First Name3 (LF) **] require repeat transfusion today if Hct continues
   to drop
   - Continue to check Q4-6H  Hct until stable
   - Continue on protonix drip per GI (18mg bolus and 8mg/hr infusion)
   - Out-patient colonoscopy
   #) Respiratory distress and aortic stenosis--most likely due to flash
   pulmonary edema due to severe AS in the setting of transfusion, IVF.
   Euvolemic yesterday after 3U PRBCs and 1U FFP with 40mg IV of lasix
   - Start to wean mechanical ventilation to pressure support
depending on
   continued transfusion requirements, may not be able to extubate today.
   - Judicious use of lasix during transfusion for aortic stenosis; may
   need to focus on GIB now with plan to optimize pulmonary status as HD
   improves
   - CXRs QD for monitoring of volume status
   - Arterial line for improved HD monitoring
   - Out-patient discussion of aortic valve replacement.
   #) Myocardial ischemia--troponin bumped from 0.11 --> 1.03, most
   recently 1.50 too high to be considered elevated from demand ischemia
   in the setting of GI bleed. Repeat EKG shows no changes from prior but
   difficult to interpret in setting of LBBB. Echo shows septal WMAs,
   consistent with mid-LAD ischemia. This may be new, since on her
   previous echo from OSH there was no mention of regional WMAs.
   - On high dose simvastatin 80mg today
   - Holding off on beta-blocker due to severe AS, heparin and ASA due to
   bleed
   - Continue cardiac enzymes to determine if levels decreasing/increasing
   - Will continue to monitor on telemetry
   - q8h EKG and cardiac enzymes
   - Possibly cardiology consult for possible cath pending resolution of
   GI bleeding.
   #) Fever--currently afebrile. Increase in temperature may have been due
   to transfusion reaction or also infection. Must consider
   hospital-acquired infections given recent discharge. Patient also has
   small abscess at back of neck. UA unremarkable.
   - Continue to follow-up microbiology data (blood and urine cultures
   from when febrile)
   - Obtain C. diff and stool cultures
   - Incision and drainage of abscess
   - Continue to monitor fever curve
   - Given abscess and continued fever, and most likely source gram
   positive organism, may consider empiric abx therapy with vancomycin
   although MRSA screen still pending.
   #) Pulmonary embolus--Currently therapeutically anticoagulated.  Per
   OSH records, small and sub-segmental.  Negative LENIs. INR 1.2.
   - F/u CTA records from OSH
   - Keep on pneumoboots for now
   - If shows any evidence of clot formation, will consider IVC filter
   placement.
   #) Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree--noted on OSH CTA without
   work-up.  Per family, no complaint of abdominal pain prior to
   admission. LFTs mildly elevated (AST 44), LDH 290. Tbili high at 1.9/D
   0.5/In 1.4 (now normal at 1.0), alk phos normal. [**Month (only) 51**] be abberant in
   setting of some liver ischemia and possible [**Doctor Last Name 4871**], but unclear at
   present.
   - When stable, will consider RUQ ultrasound
   - Obtain hemolysis labs (haptoglobin) to evaluate for whether this
   patient may be hemolyzing around thickened, stenotic valve which may
   explain the high bilirubin and LDH.
   #) Type II DM
 Unclear level of control. Finger sticks yesterday 95,
   101, 84, most recently 66
   - Continue insulin sliding scale with finger sticks qAC and HS
   #) Osteoarthritis--NSAIDs contraindicated for pain relief. Patient
   currently on Fentanyl / Midazolam gtt
   - Monitor for pain control, Fentanyl gtt
    - Hold outpatient po medications for now
    - Hold all NSAIDs
   #) Hypercholesterolemia--80 atorvastatin for myocardial ischemia.
   #) LUE pain: Etiology unclear.  [**Name2 (NI) 54**] family, this was the patient
   primary complaint today.  Prior OSH records with negative LUE u/s.
   Also with history of possible bursitis.  Given acute bleed and h/o CAD,
   obviously concerning for ischemia.
    - CE as above, ROMI
    - Control pain
    - Evaluate further as course progresses, when patient able to provide
   more details
    - Could consider x-ray of shoulder though no h/o trauma
   #) FEN:
   - Judicious fluid resuscitation given AS; A-line for improved HD
   monitoring
   - Replete lytes PRN
   #) Prophylaxis:
   - INR 1.2, holding heparin
   - Pneumoboots
   - Chlorhexadine glucontate / IV PPI gtt; daily wake-ups
   - HOB > 30 degrees

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis, recent pulmonary embolus, and type II diabetes. She was admitted with gastrointestinal bleeding and respiratory distress.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: The patient's blood pressure is 121/40 mmHg, heart rate is 55 bpm, and oxygen saturation is 98% on 40% FiO2.
* Respiratory support: The patient is mechanically ventilated with a pressure support mode, with a tidal volume of 500 mL and a positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cmH2O.
* Laboratory results: The patient's hemoglobin level is 26.8%, white blood cell count is 10.7 K/uL, and platelet count is 294 K/uL.
* Medications: The patient is receiving fentanyl, midazolam, pantoprazole, and lasix infusions, as well as protonix drips.
* Assessment and plan:
	+ Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient's hemoglobin level is decreasing, and she may require repeat transfusion. A nuclear red blood cell scan may be necessary if the bleeding continues.
	+ Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory status is improving, and she may be weaned off mechanical ventilation. However, she may not be able to be extubated today.
	+ Myocardial ischemia: The patient's troponin levels are elevated, and she may require high-dose simvastatin. She is being monitored for cardiac enzymes and may require a cardiology consult.
	+ Fever: The patient's fever may be due to a transfusion reaction or infection. She is being monitored for microbiology data and may require empiric antibiotic therapy.
	+ Pulmonary embolus: The patient is therapeutically anticoagulated and is being monitored for clot formation.
	+ Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree: The patient's liver function tests are mildly elevated, and she may require further work-up.
	+ Type II diabetes: The patient's glucose levels are being monitored, and she is receiving insulin sliding scale therapy.
	+ Osteoarthritis: The patient is receiving fentanyl and midazolam infusions for pain control.
	+ Hypercholesterolemia: The patient is receiving high-dose atorvastatin for myocardial ischemia.
	+ LUE pain: The patient's LUE pain is unclear, and she may require further evaluation.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

* Ongoing gastrointestinal bleeding
* Respiratory failure
* Cardiac ischemia or infarction
* Infection, including hospital-acquired infections
* Pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis
* Liver dysfunction or failure
* Hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia
* Osteoporosis or bone fractures
* Hypercholesterolemia or dyslipidemia

The patient's plan of care should include continued monitoring of her hemoglobin level, respiratory status, and cardiac enzymes, as well as ongoing management of her medications and fluids.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the following:

The patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis (AS), recent pulmonary embolus (PE), and gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. She was admitted with respiratory distress, likely due to flash pulmonary edema caused by severe AS in the setting of transfusion and intravenous fluid (IVF) administration.

The patient has several potential medical complications:

1. Respiratory distress: The patient is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP)/pressure support ventilation (PSV) and is being weaned off ventilation for possible extubation. However, the patient's troponin levels are still trending upwards, indicating ongoing myocardial ischemia, which may worsen respiratory distress.
2. GI bleeding: The patient has a stable hemoglobin level, and no signs of active bleeding are present. However, the patient's INR is still elevated, and she is at risk for further bleeding.
3. Myocardial ischemia: The patient's troponin levels are still elevated, indicating ongoing myocardial ischemia. This may be related to the patient's severe AS, and cardiac enzymes are being monitored every 8 hours.
4. Fever: The patient's temperature has increased, which may be due to a transfusion reaction or infection. The patient has a small abscess at the back of her neck, which is being treated with antibiotics.
5. Pulmonary embolus: The patient has a low suspicion for PE, but the study is limited due to motion artifact. If the patient shows any evidence of clot formation, an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter may be considered.
6. Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree: The patient has a significant dilatation of the intrahepatic biliary tree, which may be related to a choledochal cyst or ampullary stenosis. An endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is planned to further evaluate the patient's biliary tree.
7. Type II diabetes: The patient's glucose levels are low, and she is not receiving insulin. She is being treated with an insulin sliding scale.
8. Osteoarthritis: The patient has a history of osteoarthritis, which may be related to her chronic pain. She is currently receiving fentanyl and midazolam infusions for pain relief.
9. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient has hypercholesterolemia, which is being treated with atorvastatin.
10. LUE pain: The patient has chronic pain in her left upper extremity (LUE), which is unclear in etiology. She has a history of possible bursitis and is being treated with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning off ventilation and possible extubation
* Monitoring for ongoing myocardial ischemia and adjusting treatment as necessary
* Managing GI bleeding and bleeding risk
* Treating fever and infection
* Monitoring for pulmonary embolus and considering IVC filter placement if necessary
* Evaluating the patient's biliary tree with ERCP
* Managing type II diabetes with insulin sliding scale
* Treating osteoarthritis with fentanyl and midazolam infusions
* Managing hypercholesterolemia with atorvastatin
* Evaluating LUE pain and considering further treatment options

* Platelet count: 72-138 x 10^9/L
* Troponin: 1.50-1.35 ng/mL (indicating myocardial ischemia or repeat event)
* Creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL
* Urea: 34 mmol/L
* Electrolytes: normal
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L

Imaging studies reveal:

* Abdominal CT: significant biliary ductal dilatation, no pancreatic mass; possible choledochal cyst or ampullary stenosis
* PE CTA: limited due to motion artifact, but showing interstitial edema, which may have been an underlying cause of the patient's chronic dyspnea
* LFTs: mildly elevated AST and LDH, with normal bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Type II diabetes mellitus (DM)
* Osteoarthritis (OA)
* Hypercholesterolemia
* Myocardial ischemia
* Pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Gastrointestinal bleeding
* Possible choledochal cyst or ampullary stenosis

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Continued respiratory distress and potential need for mechanical ventilation
* Ongoing myocardial ischemia or repeat event
* Hospital-acquired infections, given the patient's recent discharge and presence of a small abscess at the back of the neck
* Development of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) or pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Gastrointestinal bleeding or perforation
* Pancreatitis or cholecystitis due to possible choledochal cyst or ampullary stenosis
* Osteoporotic fractures due to osteoarthritis and possible hypercholesterolemia

Based on the patient's condition and medical history, it is essential to monitor her closely and manage her symptoms and complications aggressively to prevent further deterioration.

   85yF with hx of severe AS and recent pulmonary embolus on coumadin
   admitted with GI bleeding and respiratory distress.
   #) Myocardial ischemia--troponin peaked at 1.50 yesterday AM, then

   for ongoing myocardial ischemia or repeat event. New regional WMAs

   - Continue high dose simvastatin at 80mg

   to severe AS in the setting of transfusion, IVF. S/p transfusion of 5U
   pRBCs and 3+ U FFP.
   - On CPAP/PSV. Wean off ventilation for plan for extubation today
   pending assured cardiac status (troponins down-trending).
   - Check I/O in PM, give lasix gingerly if positive. Goal for I=O today.
   - F/u AM CXR

   - Out-patient discussion of aortic valve replacement.
   #) GI bleeding--likely lower GI source precipitated from
   supratherapeutic INR and ascriptin use. Hct stable at 31.6 today and no
   signs of active bleeding, which is reassuring.
   - Change to [**Hospital1 7**] Hct

   Follow up with their plans, as may change in setting of ACS.
   #) Fever-- Increase in temperature may have been due to transfusion
   reaction or also infection, given climbing WBC count. Must consider
   hospital-acquired infections given recent discharge. Patient also has
   small abscess at back of neck. UA unremarkable. S/p I & D of abscess
   - Covering with unasyn for now, will d/c today
   - Will obtain repeat cultures, sputum

   unclear fever source and multiple possible etiologies including HAP,
   abscess, intra-abdominal source

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis (AS), recent pulmonary embolus, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) with gastrointestinal bleeding and respiratory distress.

The patient's current condition is stable, with a temperature of 37.8°C, heart rate of 63 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 92/35 mmHg. She is receiving mechanical ventilation with a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40% and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O.

The patient has a high risk of developing complications, including:

1. Myocardial ischemia: The patient's troponin levels have been elevated, and she has new regional wall motion abnormalities (WMAs) on echocardiogram. This suggests ongoing myocardial ischemia or a repeat event.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is unstable, and she requires mechanical ventilation. Weaning off ventilation may be challenging, and there is a risk of developing respiratory failure.
3. Sepsis: The patient has a fever, and her white blood cell count is elevated. She has a small abscess at the back of her neck, which may be a source of infection.
4. Pulmonary embolism: The patient has a history of pulmonary embolism, and her current condition may be exacerbated by her anticoagulation status.
5. Gastrointestinal bleeding: The patient has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding, and her current condition may be exacerbated by her anticoagulation status and underlying gastrointestinal disease.

The patient's laboratory results are as follows:

* Troponin: 1.50
* Creatine kinase (CK): 83
* Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH): 268 IU/L
* Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 18 IU/L
* Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 30 IU/L
* Alkaline phosphatase (ALP): 83 IU/L
* Total bilirubin (Tbili): 1.9 mg/dL
* Direct bilirubin (Dbili): 0.5 mg/dL
* Indirect bilirubin (Ibili): 1.4 mg/dL
* Albumin: 3.0 g/dL
* Lactic acid: 0.8 mmol/L

The patient's imaging studies are as follows:

* Abdominal CT: Significant biliary ductal dilatation, but no pancreatic mass. Left adrenal thickening without nodule.
* Pulmonary embolism CT: Limited study due to motion artifact, but low suspicion for pulmonary embolism.

The patient's plan of care includes:

1. Cardiology consult/path when more stable.
2. Continue high-dose simvastatin at 80 mg.
3. Continue to cycle cardiac enzymes q8h.
4. Wean off ventilation for plan for extubation today pending assured cardiac status (troponins downtrending).
5. Check I/O in PM, give lasix gingerly if positive. Goal for I=O today.
6. F/u AM CXR.
7. Arterial line for improved HD monitoring.
8. Out-patient discussion of aortic valve replacement.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex, and she requires close monitoring and management to prevent complications and optimize her care.

   Assessment and Plan
   85yF with hx of severe AS and recent pulmonary embolus on coumadin
   admitted with GI bleeding and respiratory distress.
   #) Respiratory distress--most likely due to flash pulmonary edema due
   to severe AS in the setting of transfusion, IVF. S/p transfusion of 5U
   pRBCs and 3+ U FFP. Currently running negative compared to admission.
   [**Month (only) 51**] have a component of developing pneumonia which may compromise
   respiratory status.
   - On CPAP/PSV. Wean off ventilation for plan for extubation today.
   - Have IV NTG available during extubation in case pressures rise
   - Fentanyl PRN for pain after extubation.
   - Check I/O in PM no more lasix. Would like stay even to slightly
   positive given that she has diuresed close to 2L over the last several
   days and her JVP is flat, so watch carefully for post-extubation
   auto-diuresis.
   #) Myocardial ischemia--troponin down-trending once again, most
   recently 1.03 at 3am. Cards believes this to be consistent with demand
   ischemia in setting of GI bleed
   - Continue high dose simvastatin at 80mg and ASA 325mg
   - F/u BP today. If high, NTG vs low-dose beta blocker per cardiology
   recs
   - Can stop tracking enzymes unless pt reports new symptoms
   - Cardiology will talk to patient's out-patient cardiologist re:
   potential percutaneous AVR.
   #) Fever-- Has remained febrile with low-grade temperature although
   currently afebrile. Potential sources include VAP/HAP (new developing
   opacity on left hemithorax concerning for evolving infectious process)
   vs abscess (s/p I+D), or less likely, abdominal pathology, no central
   line. WBC count trending down, which is reassuring.
   - Continue vanc/cefepime for broad antibiotic coverage for VAP (LLL)
   for 8 day course
   - Continued management of packing in abscess
   - F/u micro data: blood cultures, abscess cultures, respiratory
   cultures
   #) GI bleeding--likely lower GI source precipitated from
   supratherapeutic INR and ascriptin use. Hct stable at 28.7 <-- 29.4 <--
   31.6 today and no signs of active bleeding, which is reassuring.
   - Change to [**Hospital1 7**] Hct; will continue [**Hospital1 7**] since started heparin and
   high-dose ASA recently.
   - Protonix 40 QD
   - No need for further FFP (INR 2.1) s/p 3+ U FFP and 5mg vitamin K x1.
   - GI signing off at this time, will follow from afar; possible scope
   from below when patient is stable +/- ERCP.
   #) Abnormal Chest CT
initial concern for pulmonary embolus now felt
   unlikely, anticoagulation reversed in setting of critical GI bleed. INR
   1.2. Reviewed OSH PE CTA with radiologist and study is limited owing to
   motion artifact so difficult to assess small and subsegmental vessels.
   Low suspicion for PE, but again, limited study. Rads also noted
   interstitial edema on PE CTA, which may have been underlying cause of
   patient
s chronic dyspnea when presented to OSH.
   - Keep on pneumoboots and heparin for now
   #) Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree--noted on OSH CTA without
   work-up.  Per family, no complaint of abdominal pain prior to
   admission. LFTs mildly elevated (AST 44), LDH 290. Tbili high at 1.9/D
   0.5/In 1.4 (now normal at 1.0), alk phos normal. Rads noted ductal
   dilatation was significant and suggested abdominal CT to evaluate
   pancreas; prelim read shows no pancreatic mass but possible choledochal
   cyst.
   - No ERCP for now
   #) Type II DM
 Unclear level of control. Glucose low, not getting
   insulin.
   - Will hold insulin sliding scale with finger sticks qAC and HS, given
   that Pt not requiring insulin
   #) Osteoarthritis--NSAIDs contraindicated for pain relief. Patient
   currently on Fentanyl / Midazolam gtt
   - Monitor for pain control, Fentanyl gtt
    - Hold outpatient po medications for now
    - Hold all NSAIDs
   #) Hypercholesterolemia--80 atorvastatin for myocardial ischemia.
   #) FEN:
   - Make NPO
   - Judicious fluid resuscitation given AS; A-line for improved HD
   monitoring
   - Replete lytes PRN
   #) Constipation: has not had bowel movement since Sunday. Expect her to
   move bowels once tube feeds are further advanced.
   - Colace + Bisacodyl x 1 today
   #) Prophylaxis:
   - SCH heparin
   - Pneumoboots
   - Chlorhexadine glucontate / Protonix [**Hospital1 7**]
   - HOB > 30 degrees
   #) Access

   - R arterial line

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications can arise:

1. Respiratory Distress: The patient's respiratory status is compromised due to flash pulmonary edema, and there is a risk of developing pneumonia, which may further compromise respiratory status.
2. Myocardial Ischemia: The patient's troponin levels are trending down, but cardiac ischemia is still a concern, particularly in the setting of GI bleed.
3. Fever: The patient's low-grade temperature may be due to various causes, including VAP/HAP, abscess, or abdominal pathology. Continued monitoring of micro data and cultures is necessary to determine the cause.
4. GI Bleeding: Although the patient's Hct is stable, there is still a risk of ongoing bleeding, particularly with the patient's history of severe AS and recent pulmonary embolus.
5. Abnormal Chest CT: The patient's initial concern for pulmonary embolus is unlikely, but anticoagulation has been reversed due to critical GI bleed. Continued monitoring of coagulation parameters is necessary.
6. Dilated Intrahepatic Biliary Tree: The patient's LFTs are mildly elevated, and there is a risk of pancreatitis or choledochal cyst.
7. Type II DM: The patient's glucose levels are low, and it is unclear whether they are under control. Continued monitoring of glucose levels is necessary.
8. Osteoarthritis: The patient is currently on Fentanyl and Midazolam for pain relief, and NSAIDs are contraindicated. Monitor for pain control and consider alternative pain management options.
9. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient is currently on atorvastatin for myocardial ischemia.
10. Constipation: The patient has not had a bowel movement since Sunday and may require further intervention to manage constipation.

The patient's current medications include:

* Furosemide (Lasix) for fluid management
* Pantoprazole (Protonix) for GI bleeding prophylaxis
* Heparin Sodium for anticoagulation
* Atorvastatin for hypercholesterolemia
* Fentanyl and Midazolam for pain relief
* Colace and Bisacodyl for constipation prophylaxis
* Chlorhexadine glucontate for skin prophylaxis

The patient's plan includes:

* Weaning off ventilation for extubation today
* Monitoring of respiratory status and oxygenation
* Continued management of GI bleeding and prophylaxis
* Monitoring of coagulation parameters and anticoagulation therapy
* Management of dilated intrahepatic biliary tree and potential pancreatitis or choledochal cyst
* Monitoring of glucose levels and type II DM control
* Management of osteoarthritis and pain relief
* Monitoring of constipation and bowel movements
* Prophylaxis for VAP/HAP and abscess

The patient's disposition is ICU until at least 24 hours post-extubation.

   Acid:0.7 mmol/L, Albumin:2.6 g/dL, LDH:224 IU/L, Ca++:8.3 mg/dL,
   Mg++:2.1 mg/dL, PO4:4.4 mg/dL
   Micro:
   Urine culture: neg
   MRSA screen: neg
   Blood cultures: pending
   Respiratory cultures: not collected
   Assessment and Plan
   85yF with hx of severe AS and recent pulmonary embolus on coumadin
   admitted with GI bleeding and respiratory distress.
   #) Respiratory distress--most likely due to flash pulmonary edema due
   to severe AS in the setting of transfusion, IVF. S/p transfusion of 5U
   pRBCs and 3+ U FFP. Currently running negative compared to admission.
   [**Month (only) 51**] have a component of developing pneumonia which may compromise
   respiratory status.
   - On CPAP/PSV. Wean off ventilation for plan for extubation today
   - Fentanyl PRN for pain after extubation.
   - Check I/O in PM no more lasix. Would like stay even to slightly
   positive given that she has diuresed close to 2L over the last several
   days and her JVP is flat.
   - F/u AM CXR
   #) Myocardial ischemia--troponin down-trending once again, most
   recently 1.03 at 3am. Cards believes this to be consistent with demand
   ischemia in setting of GI bleed
   - Continue high dose simvastatin at 80mg and ASA 325mg
   - F/u BP today. If high, can start low-dose beta blocker per cardiology
   recs
   - 11am cardiac enzymes; continue another three sets to monitor for any
   new cardiac injury that may occur in the context of the stress of
   extubation.
   - Cardiology will talk to patient's out-patient cardiologist re:
   potential percutaneous AVR.
   #) Fever-- Has remained febrile with low-grade temperature although
   currently afebrile. Potential sources include abscess (s/p I&D),
   VAP/HAP (new developing opacity on left hemithorax concerning for
   evolving infectious process), or less likely, abdominal pathology. WBC
   count trending down, which is reassuring.
   - Continue vanc/cefepime for broad antibiotic coverage for VAP.
   - Continued management of packing in abscess
   - F/u micro data: blood cultures, abscess cultures, respiratory
   cultures
   #) GI bleeding--likely lower GI source precipitated from
   supratherapeutic INR and ascriptin use. Hct stable at 28.7 <-- 29.4 <--
   31.6 today and no signs of active bleeding, which is reassuring.
   - Change to [**Hospital1 7**] Hct; will continue [**Hospital1 7**] since started heparin and
   high-dose ASA recently.
   - Protonix 40 QD
   - No need for further FFP (INR 2.1) s/p 3+ U FFP and 5mg vitamin K x1.
   - Per GI, will scope from below when patient is stable and on floor.
   [**Month (only) 51**] also do ERCP at that time.
   #) Pulmonary embolus
Anticoagulation reversed in setting of critical GI
   bleed. INR 1.2. Reviewed OSH PE CTA with radiologist and study is
   limited owing to motion artifact so difficult to assess small and
   subsegmental vessels. Low suspicion for PE, but again, limited study.
   Rads also noted interstitial edema on PE CTA, which may have been
   underlying cause of patient
s chronic dyspnea when presented to OSH.
   - Keep on pneumoboots and heparin for now
   #) Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree--noted on OSH CTA without
   work-up.  Per family, no complaint of abdominal pain prior to
   admission. LFTs mildly elevated (AST 44), LDH 290. Tbili high at 1.9/D
   0.5/In 1.4 (now normal at 1.0), alk phos normal. Rads noted ductal
   dilatation was significant and suggested abdominal CT to evaluate
   pancreas; prelim read shows no pancreatic mass but possible choledochal
   cyst.
   - GI may ERCP on floor
   #) Type II DM
 Unclear level of control. Glucose low, not getting
   insulin.
   - Will hold insulin sliding scale with finger sticks qAC and HS, given
   that Pt not requiring insulin
   #) Osteoarthritis--NSAIDs contraindicated for pain relief. Patient
   currently on Fentanyl / Midazolam gtt
   - Monitor for pain control, Fentanyl gtt
    - Hold outpatient po medications for now
    - Hold all NSAIDs
   #) Hypercholesterolemia--80 atorvastatin for myocardial ischemia.
   #) FEN:
   - Tube feeds started
   - Judicious fluid resuscitation given AS; A-line for improved HD
   monitoring
   - Replete lytes PRN
   #) Constipation: has not had bowel movement since Sunday. Expect her to
   move bowels once tube feeds are further advanced.
   - Colace x 1 today
   #) Prophylaxis:
   - SCH heparin
   - Pneumoboots
   - Chlorhexadine glucontate / Protonix [**Hospital1 7**]
   - HOB > 30 degrees
   #) Access
   -18 and 20 PIVs
   - R arterial line
   #) Communication: Patient and daughter (Family meeting held on arrival
   to ICU, HCP [**Name (NI) 11111**] [**Name (NI) 13842**] [**0-0-**], [**Telephone/Fax (1) 13843**] (cell)
   #) Code:  FULL CODE
   #) Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

Summary:

The patient is an 85-year-old female admitted to the ICU with severe aortic stenosis (AS), recent pulmonary embolus (PE), GI bleeding, and respiratory distress. She has undergone transfusions of packed red blood cells (pRBCs) and fresh frozen plasma (FFP). Her troponin levels have been trending down, indicating possible demand ischemia. She has a history of type II diabetes, hypercholesterolemia, and osteoarthritis.

The patient's current status includes:

* Respiratory distress, likely due to flash pulmonary edema, which is being managed with CPAP/PSV ventilation.
* Myocardial ischemia, which is being monitored with serial cardiac enzymes.
* Fever, which is being treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and managed with packing in an abscess.
* GI bleeding, which is being managed with proton pump inhibitors and anticoagulation reversal.
* Pulmonary embolism, which is being treated with heparin and pneumoboots.
* Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree, which is being evaluated with abdominal CT.
* Type II diabetes, which is being managed with insulin sliding scale.
* Osteoarthritis, which is being managed with fentanyl and midazolam infusions.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory distress may worsen if not properly managed with CPAP/PSV ventilation.
2. Cardiac complications: The patient's myocardial ischemia may lead to cardiac arrest or arrhythmias if not properly monitored and managed.
3. Infection: The patient's fever and abscess may lead to sepsis or systemic infection if not properly managed with antibiotics and wound care.
4. GI bleeding: The patient's GI bleeding may worsen if not properly managed with proton pump inhibitors and anticoagulation reversal.
5. Pulmonary embolism: The patient's PE may worsen if not properly managed with heparin and pneumoboots.
6. Intrahepatic biliary tree complications: The patient's dilated intrahepatic biliary tree may lead to cholangitis or pancreatitis if not properly managed with antibiotics and imaging studies.
7. Diabetes complications: The patient's type II diabetes may lead to hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia if not properly managed with insulin sliding scale.
8. Osteoarthritis complications: The patient's osteoarthritis may lead to joint pain or swelling if not properly managed with fentanyl and midazolam infusions.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust ventilation settings as needed.
2. Continue to monitor the patient's cardiac status and adjust medication regimens as needed.
3. Continue to manage the patient's fever and abscess with antibiotics and wound care.
4. Continue to manage the patient's GI bleeding with proton pump inhibitors and anticoagulation reversal.
5. Continue to manage the patient's PE with heparin and pneumoboots.
6. Continue to evaluate the patient's intrahepatic biliary tree with abdominal CT and manage any complications that arise.
7. Continue to manage the patient's type II diabetes with insulin sliding scale.
8. Continue to manage the patient's osteoarthritis with fentanyl and midazolam infusions.

Based on the progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old female with a history of severe aortic stenosis (AS), recent pulmonary embolism (PE), and chronic type II diabetes mellitus (DM). She was admitted with gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding and respiratory distress.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory status: The patient is on continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) and pressure support ventilation (PSV) with a respiratory rate of 11 breaths per minute and a SpO2 of 97%. The patient is expected to be weaned off ventilation and extubated today.
* Cardiac status: The patient has myocardial ischemia, as evidenced by a trending down troponin level. Cardiology recommends continuing high-dose simvastatin and aspirin, and may start a low-dose beta blocker if the patient's blood pressure is high.
* Fever: The patient's fever has remained low-grade, and potential sources include abscess, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), or abdominal pathology. The patient is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime for broad antibiotic coverage.
* GI bleeding: The patient's GI bleeding is likely due to a lower GI source, precipitated by supratherapeutic international normalized ratio (INR) and aspirin use. The patient's hemoglobin (Hct) is stable, and no signs of active bleeding are present.
* Pulmonary embolism: The patient's PE was reversed in the setting of critical GI bleeding, and anticoagulation has been discontinued. The patient is being kept on pneumoboots and heparin for now.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is precarious, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure.
* Cardiac complications: The patient's myocardial ischemia could lead to cardiac arrhythmias, heart failure, or even cardiac arrest.
* Infection: The patient's low-grade fever and potential sources of infection, such as abscess, VAP, or abdominal pathology, could lead to sepsis or septic shock.
* GI bleeding: The patient's GI bleeding could worsen, leading to anemia, hemorrhagic shock, or even death.
* Pulmonary embolism: The patient's PE could recur, leading to further respiratory compromise or even death.

The patient's current medications include:

* Simvastatin 80mg daily
* Aspirin 325mg daily
* Vancomycin and cefepime for broad antibiotic coverage
* Fentanyl and midazolam for pain management
* Protonix 40mg daily
* Heparin for anticoagulation
* Pneumoboots for PE prophylaxis
* Chlorhexadine gluconate and Protonix for wound care

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Weaning off ventilation and extubation today
* Monitoring for pain control and adjusting medication as needed
* Managing the patient's GI bleeding and potential sources of infection
* Continuing anticoagulation therapy for now
* Monitoring the patient's respiratory status and adjusting therapy as needed
* Considering ERCP on the floor for further evaluation of the patient's dilated intrahepatic biliary tree.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old female admitted to the ICU with a history of severe aortic stenosis, recent pulmonary embolus, and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient has undergone extubation and has been experiencing poor urine output, with a creatinine level of 0.9. She has also had a frankly bloody maroon-colored bowel movement.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a heart rate of 78 beats per minute, blood pressure of 148/54 mmHg, and oxygen saturation of 99%. Her respiratory support consists of nasal cannula oxygen and continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) with a peak inspiratory pressure of 6 cmH2O.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 8.7 K/uL, hemoglobin of 9.0 g/dL, and platelet count of 265 K/uL. Her liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 15 and an alkaline phosphatase (ALK) level of 79 IU/L. Her troponin level is 1.24 ng/mL, and her lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) level is 224 IU/L.

The patient has been diagnosed with a possible abscess, and cultures have been sent for further evaluation. She has also been treated with antibiotics for suspected ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Continued bleeding: The patient's bloody stool and recent pulmonary embolus may indicate ongoing bleeding, which could worsen her condition.
2. Infection: The patient's abscess and VAP diagnoses increase her risk of developing sepsis, which could lead to organ failure.
3. Respiratory distress: The patient's respiratory support may not be adequate, and she may require further interventions to manage her respiratory status.
4. Cardiac complications: The patient's history of myocardial ischemia and recent pulmonary embolus may increase her risk of cardiac complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.
5. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's bloody stool and possible abscess may indicate gastrointestinal complications, such as perforation or obstruction.
6. Renal complications: The patient's poor urine output and elevated creatinine level may indicate renal complications, such as acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease.
7. Liver complications: The patient's mildly elevated liver function tests may indicate liver complications, such as hepatitis or cirrhosis.

Overall, the patient requires close monitoring and management to address her various medical complications and prevent further deterioration.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following medical complications may arise:

1. GI bleeding: The patient has a history of severe AS and recent pulmonary embolus, which may have contributed to the development of GI bleeding. The patient's INR is elevated, and the bleeding may not have stopped completely. Further monitoring is necessary to ensure that the bleeding does not recur.
2. Respiratory distress: The patient had respiratory distress prior to extubation, and although it has resolved, there is a risk of recurring respiratory distress due to the patient's underlying lung disease.
3. Fever: The patient has a fever, which may be related to VAP/HAP, abscess, or abdominal pathology. Further investigation is necessary to determine the source of the fever and to ensure that it is treated promptly.
4. Myocardial ischemia: The patient has troponin elevation, which may be related to demand ischemia in the setting of GI bleeding. Further monitoring is necessary to ensure that the patient's cardiac condition does not deteriorate.
5. Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree: The patient has a dilated intrahepatic biliary tree, which may be related to chronic liver disease or pancreatitis. Further investigation is necessary to determine the cause of the dilatation and to ensure that it does not lead to complications.
6. Abnormal Chest CT: The patient has an abnormal Chest CT, which may be related to pulmonary embolus or interstitial edema. Further investigation is necessary to determine the cause of the abnormality and to ensure that it does not lead to complications.
7. Type II DM: The patient has Type II DM, which may be poorly controlled. Further monitoring is necessary to ensure that the patient's blood glucose levels remain within a safe range.
8. Osteoarthritis: The patient has osteoarthritis, which may be related to chronic pain and discomfort. Further monitoring is necessary to ensure that the patient's pain is managed effectively.
9. Hypercholesterolemia: The patient has hypercholesterolemia, which may be related to a high risk of cardiovascular disease. Further monitoring is necessary to ensure that the patient's cholesterol levels remain within a safe range.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, the following plan of care is recommended:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's GI bleeding and ensure that it does not recur.
2. Monitor the patient's respiratory status and ensure that respiratory distress does not recur.
3. Investigate the source of the patient's fever and treat it promptly.
4. Monitor the patient's cardiac condition and ensure that it does not deteriorate.
5. Investigate the cause of the patient's dilated intrahepatic biliary tree and ensure that it does not lead to complications.
6. Monitor the patient's abnormal Chest CT and ensure that it does not lead to complications.
7. Monitor the patient's Type II DM and ensure that it is well-controlled.
8. Manage the patient's osteoarthritis and ensure that it does not lead to complications.
9. Monitor the patient's hypercholesterolemia and ensure that it does not lead to cardiovascular disease.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, the following medications are recommended:

1. Antibiotics: The patient is currently receiving antibiotics for VAP/HAP, abscess, and respiratory infections. The antibiotics should be continued for the full course of treatment.
2. Pain medication: The patient is currently receiving oxycodone for pain relief. The medication should be continued as needed to manage the patient's pain.
3. Anti-inflammatory medication: The patient is currently receiving protonix for gastroesophageal reflux disease. The medication should be continued as needed to manage the patient's symptoms.
4. Anticoagulation medication: The patient is currently receiving heparin for anticoagulation. The medication should be continued as needed to prevent thrombosis.
5. Lipid-lowering medication: The patient is currently receiving atorvastatin for hypercholesterolemia. The medication should be continued as needed to manage the patient's cholesterol levels.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, the following laboratory tests are recommended:

1. Complete blood count: The patient should have a complete blood count done regularly to monitor for signs of infection or bleeding.
2. Blood chemistry: The patient should have blood chemistry tests done regularly to monitor for signs of liver or kidney dysfunction.
3. Troponin: The patient should have troponin levels checked regularly to monitor for signs of cardiac damage.
4. Electrolytes: The patient should have electrolyte levels checked regularly to monitor for signs of electrolyte imbalance.
5. Lipid profile: The patient should have a lipid profile done regularly to monitor for signs of hypercholesterolemia.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, the following imaging studies are recommended:

1. Chest CT: The patient should have a Chest CT done regularly to monitor for signs of pulmonary embolus or interstitial edema.
2. Abdominal CT: The patient should have an abdominal CT done regularly to monitor for signs of abdominal pathology.
3. Echocardiogram: The patient should have an echocardiogram done regularly to monitor for signs of cardiac damage.
4. MRI: The patient should have an MRI done regularly to monitor for signs of dilated intrahepatic biliary tree or pancreatitis.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, the following surgical interventions are recommended:

1. ERCP: The patient should have an ERCP done to investigate the cause of the patient's dilated intrahepatic biliary tree.
2. Cholecystectomy: The patient should have a cholecystectomy done if the patient's dilated intrahepatic biliary tree is caused by a gallstone.
3. Pancreatectomy: The patient should have a pancreatectomy done if the patient's dilated intrahepatic biliary tree is caused by pancreatitis.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, the following other interventions are recommended:

1. Nutritional support: The patient should have nutritional support provided to ensure that the patient is receiving adequate nutrition.
2. Physical therapy: The patient should have physical therapy provided to ensure that the patient is able to perform daily activities safely and effectively.
3. Occupational therapy: The patient should have occupational therapy provided to ensure that the patient is able to perform daily activities safely and effectively.
4. Speech therapy: The patient should have speech therapy provided to ensure that the patient is able to communicate effectively.

Based on the patient's medical history and current condition, the following disposition is recommended:

1. Transfer to a rehabilitation facility: The patient should be transferred to a rehabilitation facility to ensure that the patient receives comprehensive rehabilitation services.
2. Transfer to a skilled nursing facility: The patient should be transferred to a skilled nursing facility to ensure that the patient receives skilled nursing care.
3. Discharge to home: The patient should be discharged to home with close follow-up and support to ensure that the patient is able to manage their condition safely and effectively.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 85-year-old female admitted with severe aortic stenosis, recent pulmonary embolus, and GI bleeding. She is currently in the ICU for respiratory distress and has been extubated.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36°C, heart rate of 78 bpm, and blood pressure of 148/54 mmHg. Her respiratory status is improving, with a PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 268, indicating adequate oxygenation.

The patient's laboratory results show a stable hematocrit, with a current value of 29.3%. Her white blood cell count is trending down, with a current value of 8.7 K/uL. Her liver function tests are mildly elevated, with an AST of 44 and LDH of 290. Her troponin level is down-trending, consistent with demand ischemia.

The patient has several potential medical complications that need to be monitored and managed:

1. GI bleeding: The patient has had a frankly bloody maroon-colored bowel movement, and her hematocrit is stable. However, her INR is elevated, and she is at risk for ongoing bleeding. She will be continued on protonix 40 QD and will be monitored for signs of bleeding.
2. Respiratory distress: The patient had respiratory distress prior to extubation, but it has resolved. However, she still has crackles at the bases of her lungs, and her oxygen saturation is 99% on 2L. She will be continued on oxygen therapy and will be monitored for signs of respiratory distress.
3. Fever: The patient's fever has remained afebrile over the past 24 hours, and her WBC count is trending down. However, she has a new developing opacity on her left hemithorax, which may be an evolving infectious process. She will be continued on vanc/cefepime for broad antibiotic coverage.
4. Myocardial ischemia: The patient's troponin level is down-trending, consistent with demand ischemia. She will be continued on high-dose simvastatin and will be monitored for signs of ischemia.
5. Dilated intrahepatic biliary tree: The patient has a dilated intrahepatic biliary tree, which may be related to her chronic dyspnea. She will be monitored for signs of biliary obstruction and will be considered for ERCP or MRCP if necessary.
6. Abnormal chest CT: The patient's chest CT shows an abnormality that may be related to her chronic dyspnea. She will be monitored for signs of pulmonary embolism and will be considered for further imaging if necessary.

In summary, the patient is at risk for several medical complications, including GI bleeding, respiratory distress, fever, myocardial ischemia, dilated intrahepatic biliary tree, and abnormal chest CT. She will need to be closely monitored and managed to prevent and treat these complications.
